papers.title: Discovering Differences in Strategic Behavior Between Humans and LLMs
papers.description:
arXiv:2602.10324v1 Announce Type: new 
Abstract: As Large Language Models (LLMs) are increasingly deployed in social and strategic scenarios, it becomes critical to understand where and why their behavior diverges from that of humans. While behavioral game theory (BGT) provides a framework for analy
papers.author: Caroline Wang, Daniel Kasenberg, Kim Stachenfeld, Pablo Samuel Castro

papers.title: LiveMedBench: A Contamination-Free Medical Benchmark for LLMs with Automated Rubric Evaluation
papers.description:
arXiv:2602.10367v1 Announce Type: new 
Abstract: The deployment of Large Language Models (LLMs) in high-stakes clinical settings demands rigorous and reliable evaluation. However, existing medical benchmarks remain static, suffering from two critical limitations: (1) data contamination, where test s
papers.author: Zhiling Yan, Dingjie Song, Zhe Fang, Yisheng Ji, Xiang Li, Quanzheng Li, Lichao Sun

papers.title: Found-RL: foundation model-enhanced reinforcement learning for autonomous driving
papers.description:
arXiv:2602.10458v1 Announce Type: new

papers.author: Yansong Qu, Zihao Sheng, Zilin Huang, Jiancong Chen, Yuhao Luo, Tianyi Wang, Yiheng Feng, Samuel Labi, Sikai Chen

papers.title: MERIT Feedback Elicits Better Bargaining in LLM Negotiators
papers.description:
arXiv:2602.10467v1 Announce Type: new 
Abstract: Bargaining is often regarded as a logical arena rather than an art or a matter of intuition, yet Large Language Models (LLMs) still struggle to navigate it due to limited strategic depth and difficulty adapting to complex human factors. Current benchm
papers.author: Jihwan Oh, Murad Aghazada, Yooju Shin, Se-Young Yun, Taehyeon Kim

papers.title: Abstraction Generation for Generalized Planning with Pretrained Large Language Models
papers.description:
arXiv:2602.10485v1 Announce Type: new 
Abstract: Qualitative Numerical Planning (QNP) serves as an important abstraction model for generalized planning (GP), which aims to compute general plans that solve multiple instances at once. Recent works show that large language models (LLMs) can function as
papers.author: Zhenhe Cui, Huaxiang Xia, Hangjun Shen, Kailun Luo, Yong He, Wei Liang

papers.title: Flow of Spans: Generalizing Language Models to Dynamic Span-Vocabulary via GFlowNets
papers.description:
arXiv:2602.10583v1 Announce Type: new 
Abstract: Standard autoregressive language models generate text token-by-token from a fixed vocabulary, inducing a tree-structured state space when viewing token sampling as an action, which limits flexibility and expressiveness. Recent work introduces dynamic
papers.author: Bo Xue, Yunchong Song, Fanghao Shao, Xuekai Zhu, Lin Chen, Luoyi Fu, Xinbing Wang, Zhouhan Lin

papers.title: Neuro-symbolic Action Masking for Deep Reinforcement Learning
papers.description:
arXiv:2602.10598v1 Announce Type: new 
Abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) may explore infeasible actions during training and execution. Existing approaches assume a symbol grounding function that maps high-dimensional states to consistent symbolic representations and a manually specified ac
papers.author: Shuai Han, Mehdi Dastani, Shihan Wang

papers.title: To Think or Not To Think, That is The Question for Large Reasoning Models in Theory of Mind Tasks
papers.description:
arXiv:2602.10625v1 Announce Type: new 
Abstract: Theory of Mind (ToM) assesses whether models can infer hidden mental states such as beliefs, desires, and intentions, which is essential for natural social interaction. Although recent progress in Large Reasoning Models (LRMs) has boosted step-by-step
papers.author: Nanxu Gong, Haotian Li, Sixun Dong, Jianxun Lian, Yanjie Fu, Xing Xie

papers.title: OmniSapiens: A Foundation Model for Social Behavior Processing via Heterogeneity-Aware Relative Policy Optimization
papers.description:

Abstract: To develop socially intelligent AI, existing approaches typically model human behavioral dimensions (e.g., affective, cognitive, or social attributes) in isolation. Although useful, task-specific modeling often increases training costs and limits gene
papers.author: Keane Ong, Sabri Boughorbel, Luwei Xiao, Chanakya Ekbote, Wei Dai, Ao Qu, Jingyao Wu, Rui Mao, Ehsan Hoque, Erik Cambria, Gianmarco Mengaldo, Paul Pu Liang
